title: Team USA Lost to France, and It Wasn’t a Fluke
text:
A star from Greece won the Most Valuable Player award, a phenom from Slovenia by way of Spain won Rookie of the Year honors and the last NBA season had so much global influence that it felt oddly appropriate for the championship to be won by the only team outside the U.S.

So maybe the most surprising result in more than a decade of international basketball—Team USA losing to France, 89-79, in the quarterfinals of the FIBA World Cup on Wednesday—shouldn’t have been much of a surprise.

The loss snapped the Americans’ 58-game winning streak in major international tournaments with NBA players, a streak that went back to 2006, and it meant the U.S. won’t medal in an Olympics or World Cup for the first time since a disastrous performance in 2002. The repeated failure to win gold in 2002, 2004 and 2006 was the last time that USA Basketball found itself at the crossroads that it’s suddenly facing before next summer’s Olympics. That reckoning brought about the Redeem Team in 2008, and the U.S. hadn’t lost since then.

But the problem is that the best American players no longer seem interested in playing basketball pro bono at a time when the rest of the world is only getting better.

It wasn’t the fault of the players on the team. Gregg Popovich and USA Basketball weren’t to blame, either. It was simply a reflection of a league that has changed dramatically since the last World Cup five years ago. That’s why an upset in the first game of the knockout round wasn’t humiliating in the way that past American losses have felt like international embarrassments. This one seemed almost inevitable.

The big question now is whether a sense of urgency will return in time for the 2020 Olympics—or whether this marked the end of an era of American basketball hegemony.

This surprisingly uncertain era of USA Basketball began in a gruesome way one night in 2014. Paul George hustled back to defend a fast-break layup in a meaningless intrasquad scrimmage, and this admirable play would have a scarring psychic effect across the league. George crashed into the basket stanchion and broke his leg in a grisly visual reminder of the risks that NBA players assume when they suit up for their country without getting paid. It had been cool to play for Team USA. Now it seemed foolish.

George returned to play in 2016 with Kevin Durant, Kyrie Irving and Klay Thompson. But for the first time since 2004, when a lackluster roster prompted USA Basketball to rethink the identity of the national team, the team was defined by who wasn’t playing and not who was. Team USA went to Rio de Janeiro without LeBron James, Kawhi Leonard, Stephen Curry, James Harden and Russell Westbrook. They struggled in the group stage against Australia, squeaked past Serbia and barely survived a pesky French team before they recovered to win their third straight gold medal.

By the time France pulled off the upset on Wednesday, though, Team USA losing was not entirely unexpected for something that almost never happens.

In his first summer coaching the U.S. national squad, Gregg Popovich took a junior-varsity Team USA to China. The biggest NBA stars once again decided to skip this competition and enjoy their summer vacations instead. It has become trickier in recent years to convince players of their caliber to volunteer in their spare time out of patriotic spirit. That’s not just because the image of George’s injury is seared in their minds. It’s also because they are increasingly mindful of rest and recovery at a time when the Toronto Raptors just won the NBA title in part because Kawhi Leonard didn’t play in a quarter of their regular-season games.

Gregg Popovich took a junior-varsity Team USA to China. Photo: Lintao Zhang/Getty Images

The players who can demand contracts worth $200 million probably weren’t going to play in the World Cup anyway. There is precedent for the U.S. tapping the next generation of players and using this tournament as a farm system for the next Olympics. But even by those standards, this American roster was vulnerable.

This tournament was the first time since before the Dream Team that the Americans didn’t have the best player (Greece’s Giannis Antetokounmpo). As if that weren’t strange enough, they also didn’t have the second best player (Serbia’s Nikola Jokic). They might not have even had the third best player (France’s Rudy Gobert).

Team USA had more NBA starters than stars, and it showed. The Americans were still the favorites, but there had never been less of a talent gap between them and the rest of the planet. They lost to Australia in an exhibition last month. They probably should have lost to Turkey last week. And they did lose to France on Wednesday.

The most remarkable thing was not that it happened but how it happened. As most Americans pretended to be European by watching basketball as they brewed their morning coffee, Team USA found itself down 10 in the third quarter on the brink of elimination. That’s when Donovan Mitchell began to play as if he’d chugged a triple espresso. He scored all 29 of his points in the first three quarters and brought Team USA back as they took a seven-point lead in the fourth quarter after the single most impressive run of their summer. It was a characteristically American performance.

But as in every other part of life, the French were not impressed.

Rudy Gobert took advantage of Team USA’s glaring weakness and bullied the undersized Americans. Photo: alex plavevski/epa/Shutterstock

Frank Ntilikina, who has the great misfortune of normally playing basketball for the New York Knicks, became useful as soon as he was in another uniform. Evan Fournier looked like one of those mysterious international players who magically seems to make every shot against the U.S. and not someone who’s on the Orlando Magic. Gobert feasted on Team USA’s undersized lineups and was so dominant that the French were +26 in 34 minutes with him and -16 in 6 minutes without him.

The glaring weaknesses of Team USA revealed themselves at the worst possible time. They didn’t have someone like Durant, James or Kobe Bryant to bend the game to his will, and they didn’t have the shooting to compensate for not having size. With their margin for error already minuscule, Team USA went 4-of-11 from the free-throw line and 1-of-5 from the 3-point line in the fourth quarter, and they went from down 10 to up seven to down 10 again as the buzzer sounded.

It was a painful reminder that international basketball is beautiful in its own funky way. The games are shorter, the court is smaller and the style of play is tougher. It’s a sport in which a team consisting entirely of NBA players can lose to a team in which more than half the roster plays overseas.

This is because NBA basketball and FIBA basketball are like spinach and kale. They look similar. But they taste and feel completely different. And one is beginning to leave a bitter taste for the Americans.

description: Team USA was upset by France, 89-79, in the quarterfinals of the FIBA World Cup on Wednesday. The loss snapped the Americans’ 58-game winning streak on the international stage with NBA players.
